title: Nicola Sturgeon to request Scottish independence referendum ‘before end of year’
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Nicola Sturgeon has said she will request UK government consent for another Scottish independence referendum before the end of the year.

Appearing on The Andrew Marr Show, Scotland’s First Minister revealed she would be asking for a Section 30 order ‘over the next matter of weeks’.

If successful, she is aiming to hold the referendum in the latter half of 2020.

The Referendums (Scotland) Bill, which makes provision for holding referendums across the country, was produced by the Scottish Government in May.

Sturgeon told Marr: ‘I’m putting legislation through the Scottish Parliament right now, to put the rules and regulations in place.

‘As that legislation progresses we will make that request for a Section 30 order.’

Asked if she will request the order this year, the SNP leader replied ‘yes’, before continuing: ‘We will do it at an appropriate moment when the legislation is passing.

Nicola Sturgeon said she will be asking for a Section 30 order ‘over the next matter of weeks’ (Picture: PA)

‘It is likely to be over the next matter of weeks. It is coming soon. Of course we don’t yet know who is likely to be in Downing Street, the situation is very fluid.’

The Scotland Act 1998 itself does not devolve power to the Scottish Parliament to authorise a referendum on independence.

This means the First Minister of Scotland needs to seek an Order in Council under Section 30(2) from the UK government.

Frantic week ahead will decide the UK's future over Brexit

Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard has already spoken out against another referendum, stating: ‘We need to resolve the constitutional crisis – not create another one’.

He added: ‘Scotland needs a Labour government that will deliver £70 billion of investment in our country. Our NHS, schools and business need this investment.

‘The prospect of a socialist Britain offers far more than that of a separate Scotland.’

While Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, argued that the people of Scotland ‘do not want or need another divisive referendum’.

The referendum would take place in the latter half of 2020 (Picture: Getty Images)

She said the request would not be granted by the UK government, adding that ‘barely a quarter of people’ support Sturgeon’s plans.

Sturgeon has held strong on her view that a legal referendum is the only route for Scotland to secure independence.

Some activists within the SNP have backed holding a Catalonian-style wildcat poll or taking winning a majority of seats at Westminster as a ‘plan B’ option for independence negotiations.

Writing in the Sunday Mail, Sturgeon declared she would not ‘fall into the trap’ of deviating from a ‘legal and constitutional’ Scottish referendum.

She said: ‘We don’t need to be talking about plan B when we have a perfectly good plan A – especially when any plan B is exactly the route many opponents of independence would like us to go down.

‘If we were to try to hold a referendum that wasn’t recognised as legal and legitimate – or to claim a mandate for independence without having demonstrated majority support for it – it would not carry the legal, political and diplomatic weight that is needed.’

description: SNP leader and Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said she is aiming for a Scottish independence referendum next year.
